text:
Well you could use Ubersuggest to show you which keywords get the highest search volumes. Keep your search broad for ideas.

But for a writer with broad enough criteria, a mere Google search can help you do the same to see what's trending.

text: Hi, I'm from a performance agency. We either built content for clients or helped build a content team. And from experience I must say that the best results and where we direct the most energy is planning and strategy. We used to do it more or less ad hoc. But now we are trying to start and adapt to our goal right from the start. Specific things that helped me: 1. Right at the beginning to determine the very important things that will accompany you later and you may find it unnecessary, that is, persona, positioning, consistency, etc. 2. The micro-level is a must have, but the macro-level is important. The micro-level represents quality writing, texts that read well, speed of execution, etc. But in order for content to deliver results, it is important to focus on the macro-level. There are questions that help me: What is our goal for this quarter? What framework and activities can help to fulfill it? At what stage of the shopping cycle should I reach people to reach it? What formats and types of content should I use? What channels will the content be intended for? Am I going after keywords or topics (pillar and cluster)? Does the content have sufficient support (on social networks, linkbuilding)?

text: Assuming we're not talking about organic search, one thing I used to do for years with my blog about writing software was to keep an eye on blogs/Hacker News/social media and, instead of an argumentative comment when I disagreed with something I saw, I'd create a blog post draft and put a link to the post in it.

text: Looking for survey responses (*Backlink opportunity!*). I'm looking for managers who are willing to share some first-time manager mistakes and what they've learned from them. <https://forms.gle/MPmzqcRYk1T3ZUKp8>

attachments.title: Survey: First-Time Manager Mistakes
attachments.text: We're working on an article for <http://Uptickapp.com|Uptickapp.com> about common mistakes that first-time managers make. "First-time" can refer to the very first time you ever worked as a manager or the first time you worked in a new management position. We're looking for insights and quotes from managers who are willing to share some of their own mistakes and what they learned from them. For this survey, please think of the human side of management. We're interested in mistakes that relate to managing people such as missteps that led to awkward situations, failing to make time for one-on-one conversations, not realizing a team member needed help, etc. All quotes will be attributed with a backlink to your site. Thank you for sharing your insights!
attachments.fallback: Google Docs: Survey: First-Time Manager Mistakes

elements.text: Looking for survey responses (
Backlink opportunity!
). I'm looking for managers who are willing to share some first-time manager mistakes and what they've learned from them.

text:
The best I have encountered is a brand lawyer willing to say via email "_don't worry about it, it's fair use_."

But I've never seen it show up in a set of tone & voice guidelines or brand guidelines. Normal brand guidelines are terrible about addressing even the most basic editorial concerns, though.

This is speaking as content agency trying to get brand teams in writing to how they want us to handle copyright / fair use concerns. Haven't had to deal with it from an internal standpoint.

elements.text: The best I have encountered is a brand lawyer willing to say via email "
don't worry about it, it's fair use

."

But I've never seen it show up in a set of tone & voice guidelines or brand guidelines. Normal brand guidelines are terrible about addressing even the most basic editorial concerns, though.

This is speaking as content agency trying to get brand teams in writing to how they want us to handle copyright / fair use concerns. Haven't had to deal with it from an internal standpoint.

text:
Ah, sigh. I'm more interested in providing guidance around when (and which) gifs are appropriate and when they're not.

On a personal level, I've definitely seen gif use that warrants applause and gif use that's just one big cringe—and not just due to the gif itself. Trying to articulate what's behind those reactions is really tricky!

elements.text:
Ah, sigh. I'm more interested in providing guidance around when (and which) gifs are appropriate and when they're not.

On a personal level, I've definitely seen gif use that warrants applause and gif use that's just one big cringe—and not just due to the gif itself. Trying to articulate what's behind those reactions is really tricky!

text:
Oh cool - IMO that is easier to address. I would just include visual guidelines attached to each section of your tone & voice, or a similar approach.

So for example we have sections like how to approach mentioning competitiors/alternatives, whether it's fair game to mention pop culture/celebrities, and then the normal stuff like is the brand "friendly, human, concise", etc. Then we have "do this not that" example for each.

I would add GIF types of guidelines into that mix and show the writers "do this, not that". Showing Keanu Reeves being frustrated is fine, showing John Wick swearing and shooting stuff is not.

Then whenever our editors encounter a new thing that a writer shouldn't have done we try and add it to the guidelines and include whatever we replaced it with.

text:
Spitballing on that more - I think you can take the same brand voice elements and apply them straight to GIFs...

Is our brand edgy? Sexy? Conservative? Happy? Bubbly? Luxurious? Post modern? All of that translates directly into GIF usage I think.
